details.title: Bathtub shaped failure rates from mixtures: a practical point of view
details.standardTitle: Bathtub shaped failure rates from mixtures: a practical point of view

p: Eshetu T. Wondmagegnehu graduated with a degree in Mathematics (1989) from Asmara University, Ethiopia; and received his M.Sc. in Statistics (1998) from the University of Alberta, Canada. He also completed his Ph.D. (2002) in Statistics from the University of Pittsburgh, PA, USA. He is an assistant professor in the Department of Statistics, Western Michigan University, MI, USA. His research interest includes small area estimation, mixtures of distributions, and reliability analysis.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Western Michigan Univ., Kalamazoo, MI, USA
authors.name: E.T. Wondmagegnehu

p: Jorge Navarro was born in Murcia, Murcia in 1966. He graduated in Mathematics (1989) in Universidad de Murcia, and received his PhD (1995) in Mathematics from Universidad de Murcia. He is an associate professor in the Department of Statistics and Operational Research at Universidad de Murcia. His research interest include characterization, stochastic ordering, mixtures of distributions, and systems reliability analysis.

Pedro J. Hernandez was born in Murcia, Murcia in 1966. He graduated with a degree in Mathematics (1989) from the Universidad de Murcia. He is an associate professor in the Department of Quantitative and Computational Methods at the Universidad Politecnica de Cartagena. His research interest include stochastic ordering, mixtures of distributions, and systems reliability analysis.

details.abstract: We show that a bathtub shaped failure rate can be obtained from a mixture of two increasing failure rate (IFR) models. Specifically, we study the failure rate of the mixture of an exponential distribution, and a Weibull distribution with strictly increasing failure rate. Under some reasonable conditions, we show that, from a practical point of view, the mixture failure rate is bathtub. Similar results can be obtained from other mixtures.
details.formulaStrippedArticleTitle: Bathtub shaped failure rates from mixtures: a practical point of view

citations.title: Bathtub shaped failure rates from mixtures: a practical point of view

context.text: This shape arises in many practical situation as lifetimes in biological populations, including humans ones (see [23]), where at extreme old age organizms exhibit decreasing hazard (failure) rate; medical data (see [1], [16]), where the initial increasing period is usually due to an aggressive treatment; and divorce rates (see [1]).
Aalen & Gjessing obtained in [1] UBFR models from a stochastic process.

links.abstract: This paper addresses some of the fundamental assumptions underlying the bathtub curve. It is shown to be unlikely that any practical hazard function is decreasing near zero. Great care should be taken in interpreting the hazard function, particularly in applying quality-control practices, such as burn-in or environmental-stress-screening to manufactured products.

context.text: [10] studied the mixtures as a method to obtain BFR models showing, under some conditions, that the mixture FR is increasing at \$t=0\$.
Similar results can be obtained for the models studied in [10], [12], [22].

[10] also considered exponential & IFR Weibull mixtures, but, the plot given in Fig. 9 in [10], obtained from \$0<t<140\$, is not reasonable in practice because \$p=0.1, \mu_{0}=100\$, and \$\mu_{1}=9.181\thinspace687\$ (i.e. the units with manufacturing defects are much better, and more common, than the units without defects).

Hence, the initial period is censored in practice, and some models with increasing failure rate in a neighborhood around 0 can be BFR in practice, as occurs in strictly IFR Weibull mixtures (see Figures 3 & 5 in [10]), or normal mixtures (see [17]).

references.title: A critical look at the bathtub curve
references.text: G. A. Klutke, P. C. Kiessler, M. A. Wortman, "A critical look at the bathtub curve", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 52, no. 1, pp. 125-129, 2003.

references.title: Some new approaches to probability distributions
references.text: S. Kotz, D. N. Shanbhag, "Some new approaches to probability distributions", Adv. Appl. Probab., vol. 12, pp. 903-921, 1980.

links.abstract: Two different indexes, the hazard rate and the renewal rate, which are implied by conventional uses of the bathtub-shaped curve, are often noted in reliability. The hazard rate is applicable for a single failure time of each item, such as that of a nonrepairable part; the renewal rate is applicable for multiple failure times of each item, such as those of repairable equipment. Occasionally, remarks are made in the literature concerning the mathematical models for the bathtub-shaped hazard rate b...

context.text: For example, Krohn [12] proposed to obtain BFR models from a mixture of three Weibull distributions (a DFR Weibull for the early failures, an exponential for the useful life period and an IFR Weibull for the wear period).
Similar results can be obtained for the models studied in [10], [12], [22].
Krohn proposed in [12] to use a mixture of a Weibull \$(\alpha<1)\$, an exponential, and a Weibull \$(\alpha>1)\$ representing early, chance, and aging failures, respectively.

references.title: Hazard versus renewal rate of electronic items

context.text: A lot of theoretical BFR models have been proposed in the literature by using different techniques; see the reviews in [13], [19] and the references given there.

links.abstract: The characterizations described use relations between the failure rate function and conditional expectation. The theorems proved here extend the results of some authors and can be used in the context of the renewal process. The utility of these results is demonstrated by using them to characterize some common distributions.

context.text: The model can be also characterized from relations between these two functions (see [20]).

context.text: Vaupel & Yashin [22] obtained plots of BFR models from mixtures of exponential, and models with linear failure rates.
The same holds for the models by Vaupel & Yashin [22].

The results given in [22] by using mixtures of exponential & linear failure rate models, can be interpreted in a similar way (i.e. in practice they are BFR).
